articles.headline: The Time Bernanke Got It Wrong
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve chairman is credited with preventing another depression in response to the debt crisis. But he missed the growing imbalances that led to the crisis.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve chairman is credited with preventing another depression in response to the debt crisis. But he missed the growing imbalances that led to the crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is amazing that a lot of criticism of the Federal Reserve today focuses on what it clearly got right — the response to the debt crisis in 2008 and thereafter, a response that may well have prevented Great Depression II — and not on what it got wrong: policies that allowed the dangerous imbalances to grow and bring on the crisis.

articles.headline: Billions in Debt, Detroit Tumbles Into Insolvency
articles.snippet: The city, the cradle of America’s automobile industry and once the nation’s fourth-most populous, is the largest American city ever to take such a course.
articles.abstract: The city, the cradle of America’s automobile industry and once the nation’s fourth-most populous, is the largest American city ever to take such a course.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Detroit, the cradle of America’s automobile industry and once the nation’s fourth-most-populous city, filed for bankruptcy on Thursday, the largest American city ever to take such a course.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Google Results Show Struggle With Mobile
articles.snippet: The second-quarter income announcement showed the desktop search business continued to slow, while ad prices fell.
articles.abstract: The second-quarter income announcement showed the desktop search business continued to slow, while ad prices fell.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For more than a year, Google has been struggling to solve this riddle: Even though people are using Google on their mobile devices more than ever, how does Google make more money on mobile ads?

articles.headline: Romanian’s Tale Has Art World Fearing the Worst
articles.snippet: Ashes from the oven of a Romanian woman contain paint and nails, indicating that she may have burned seven works stolen from a Dutch museum. Her son has been arrested in the theft.
articles.abstract: Ashes from the oven of a Romanian woman contain paint and nails, indicating that she may have burned seven works stolen from a Dutch museum. Her son has been arrested in the theft.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — To Olga Dogaru, a lifelong resident of the tiny Romanian village of Carcaliu, the strangely beautiful artworks her son had brought home in a suitcase four months earlier had become a curse.

articles.headline: JPMorgan Executive May Escape Penalty
articles.snippet: While the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and JPMorgan are negotiating a settlement, Blythe Masters, a top bank executive, is not expected to face a separate action, people briefed on the matter said.
articles.abstract: While the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and JPMorgan are negotiating a settlement, Blythe Masters, a top bank executive, is not expected to face a separate action, people briefed on the matter said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as the nation’s top energy regulator is poised to extract a record settlement from JPMorgan Chase over accusations that it manipulated power markets, the agency is expected to spare a top bank lieutenant who federal investigators initially contended made “false and misleading statements under oath,” according to people briefed on the matter.

articles.headline: Big Banks, Flooded in Profits, Fear Flurry of New Safeguards
articles.snippet: Wall Street’s big banks have reported giant profits, but they are still opposing aspects of the Dodd-Frank financial reform law and do not like a proposal to set aside more capital to cover future losses.
articles.abstract: Wall Street’s big banks have reported giant profits, but they are still opposing aspects of the Dodd-Frank financial reform law and do not like a proposal to set aside more capital to cover future losses.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s six largest banks reported $23 billion in profits in the second quarter, but they could end up victims of their own success.

articles.headline: SeaWorld’s Unusual Retort to a Critical Documentary
articles.snippet: SeaWorld Entertainment began an aggressive public pushback against the new documentary “Blackfish,” which makes the case that orca whales in captivity suffer physical and mental distress.
articles.abstract: SeaWorld Entertainment began an aggressive public pushback against the new documentary “Blackfish,” which makes the case that orca whales in captivity suffer physical and mental distress.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Hollywood has just cast SeaWorld as a bad guy. But SeaWorld has decided to diverge from the story line.

articles.headline: China’s Feud With West on Solar Leads to Tax
articles.snippet: The tariffs could exceed 50 percent on materials imported from the United States and South Korea used to build solar panels, a move seen as retaliation for an American trade lawsuit.
articles.abstract: The tariffs could exceed 50 percent on materials imported from the United States and South Korea used to build solar panels, a move seen as retaliation for an American trade lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Escalating a long-simmering trade dispute with the West over solar panels, China plans to impose tariffs that could exceed 50 percent on a material it imports from the United States and South Korea to make the panels, its Ministry of Commerce announced on Thursday.

articles.headline: G-20 Backs Plan to Curb Tax Avoidance by Large Corporations
articles.snippet: The plan aims at corporations only and, if widely adopted, would shift some of the global tax burden away from small businesses and individuals.
articles.abstract: The plan aims at corporations only and, if widely adopted, would shift some of the global tax burden away from small businesses and individuals.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The world’s richest economies for the first time endorsed a blueprint on Friday to curb widely used tax avoidance strategies that allow some multinational corporations to pay only a pittance in income taxes.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Floyd Norris

articles.headline: Kerry Achieves Deal to Revive Mideast Talks
articles.snippet: Secretary of State John Kerry said Israel and the Palestinian Authority had agreed to join him in Washington in hopes of resuming formal talks for the first time since 2010.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said Israel and the Palestinian Authority had agreed to join him in Washington in hopes of resuming formal talks for the first time since 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Israeli and Palestinian leaders have “established a basis” to resume direct peace negotiations for the first time in three years, Secretary of State John Kerry announced Friday, after an intense round of shuttle diplomacy aimed at reviving the dormant Middle East peace process.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Jodi Rudoren
